title: Cast a Spell
subtitle: Cast time of 1 bonus action
description: Cast a swift spell with a casting time of 1 bonus action, which restricts further spellcasting on your turn.
summary: Cast a spell with a 1-bonus-action casting time. If you do, the only other spell you can cast on the same turn is a cantrip with a 1-action casting time.

bullets.content: Bonus action spells provide incredible flexibility, but they come with a specific and important restriction on what other spells you can cast in the same turn. This rule is a cornerstone of the game's action economy for spellcasters.

items: If you cast any spell using a bonus action, you cannot cast another spell during the same turn, except for a cantrip with a casting time of 1 action.
For example, if you cast Misty Step (a bonus action spell), you can only cast a cantrip like Fire Bolt with your action, not another leveled spell like Magic Missile.

bullets.content: This rule prevents a caster from using two leveled spells in one turn, such as casting Healing Word as a bonus action and Cure Wounds as an action. Understanding this limitation is critical to playing a spellcaster effectively.

title: Offhand Attack
subtitle: Use with the Attack action
description: When taking the Attack action with a light weapon, use your bonus action to attack with a different light weapon in your other hand.
summary: After taking the Attack action with a Light weapon, you can use your bonus action to make one attack with a different Light weapon. You don't add your ability modifier to the bonus attack's damage.

bullets.content: This is the core rule for two-weapon fighting, allowing a character to make an additional attack at the cost of their bonus action. However, this extra attack has a key limitation on the damage it deals.

items: When you take the Attack action and attack with a light melee weapon you're holding, you can use a bonus action to attack with another light melee weapon in your other hand.
You don't add your ability modifier to the damage of the bonus attack, unless that modifier is negative.
The Two-Weapon Fighting fighting style lets you add your ability modifier to the damage, and the Dual Wielder feat removes the 'light' weapon requirement.

bullets.content: Remember, you are only eligible to make an offhand attack if you have already taken the Attack action on your turn. You cannot, for example, cast a spell with your action and then make an offhand attack.

title: Use Class Feature
subtitle: Some features use bonus actions
description: Activate a racial or class feature that uses a bonus action, as specified in the feature's description.
reference: See class page for more information.
summary: Activate a unique ability from your class, race, or other source that requires a bonus action to use, as specified in the feature's description.

bullets.content: Many classes have defining features that use a bonus action, allowing them to supplement their main action with another powerful or tactical effect. These abilities often define a class's unique rhythm in combat.

items: Examples include a Rogue's Cunning Action (Dash, Disengage, or Hide), a Monk's Martial Arts or Ki abilities, a Barbarian entering a Rage, or a Cleric using their War Priest feature.

bullets.content: Managing your bonus action is a key part of mastering these classes, as it often competes with other options like two-weapon fighting or bonus action spells.

title: Aim*
subtitle: Gain advantage on an attack
description: As a bonus action, forgo your movement this turn to grant yourself advantage on your next attack roll.
summary: If you haven't moved this turn, you can use your bonus action to gain advantage on the next attack roll you make this turn. Your speed becomes 0 for the rest of the turn.

bullets.content: This optional rule, introduced in Tasha's Cauldron of Everything, provides a clear tactical trade-off: sacrifice all mobility for a single, more accurate attack. It's a fantastic tool, especially for ranged attackers.

items: You can use this bonus action only if you haven't moved during this turn.
After using it, your speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.
This grants you advantage on the first attack roll you make on the current turn.

bullets.content: This is an excellent option for Rogues to ensure their Sneak Attack hits, or for a character with the Sharpshooter feat to help offset the -5 attack penalty.

title: Overrun*
subtitle: Run through a hostile space
description: As an action or bonus action, attempt to force your way through a hostile creature's space.
summary: As a bonus action, make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by an enemy's Athletics. If you win, you can move through their space once this turn. You have advantage if you are larger.

bullets.content: This maneuver from the Dungeon Master's Guide allows you to bull-rush past an enemy blocking your path. It relies on a contested Strength (Athletics) check to gain passage.

items: As an action or a bonus action, make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) check.
You have advantage on the check if you are larger than the target, or disadvantage if you are smaller.
If you win the contest, you can move through the hostile creature's space once on this turn.

bullets.content: Having this available as a bonus action makes it much more viable for characters who want to reposition and still take the Attack action on the same turn.

title: Tumble*
subtitle: Tumble through a hostile space
description: As an action or bonus action, attempt to deftly move through a hostile creature's space.
summary: As a bonus action, make a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by an enemy's Acrobatics. If you win, you can move through their space once this turn.

bullets.content: As an agile alternative to the Strength-based Overrun, this maneuver allows a dexterous character to slip past an opponent using a contested Dexterity (Acrobatics) check.

items: As an action or a bonus action, you make a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check contested by the target's Dexterity (Acrobatics) check.
If you win the contest, you can move through the hostile creature's space once on this turn.

bullets.content: This is an excellent bonus action for mobile characters like Monks or Rogues to navigate a crowded battlefield without sacrificing their main action.

title: Drink a Potion**
subtitle: Quaff a potion quickly
description: A popular house rule that allows you to drink a potion as a bonus action, making them more useful in combat.
summary: A popular house rule that allows you to drink a potion as a bonus action. Administering a potion to another creature remains a full action.

bullets.content: By standard rules, drinking a potion requires the Use an Object action. This common house rule speeds up play and makes potions a more attractive and viable option in the heat of battle.

items: Variant 1 (Most Common): You can drink a potion yourself as a bonus action. Administering a potion to another creature remains an action.
Variant 2 (Uncommon): Drinking a potion as a bonus action restores the rolled amount of hit points. Using a full action restores the maximum possible amount.

bullets.content: Adopting this rule can significantly change combat economy, allowing characters to both heal and attack in the same turn, which can lead to faster and more heroic encounters.

title: Feint**
subtitle: Gain advantage on your attack
description: A house rule that lets you use a bonus action and a contested skill check to gain advantage on your next attack.
summary: Use your bonus action to make a Charisma (Deception) check contested by a target's Wisdom (Insight). On a success, you gain advantage on your next attack roll against that creature this turn.

bullets.content: This homebrew provides a tactical option for creating your own advantage through subterfuge, rather than relying on positioning or allies. It creates a dueling-style mind game.

items: As a bonus action, choose a creature within 5 feet of you. Make a Charisma (Deception) check contested by its Wisdom (Insight) check.
If you succeed, you gain advantage on your next attack roll against that creature this turn.

bullets.content: This is a great thematic fit for Swashbuckler Rogues or Battle Master Fighters, adding a tactical, skill-based mechanic to their toolkit.

title: Quick Assessment**
subtitle: Gauge an enemy's condition
description: A house rule allowing a bonus action to make a skill check to learn tactical information about a foe.
summary: A house rule to use a bonus action for a skill check (e.g., Insight) to learn one piece of tactical information about an enemy, such as its vulnerabilities or current HP.

bullets.content: This rule provides a mechanic for the common desire to assess an enemy's state without spending a full action. It rewards tactical thinking and knowledge-based skills by letting you gain a quick insight.

items: As a bonus action, choose a creature you can see. Make a Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) check against a DC set by the DM (often 10 + the creature's CR).
On a success, the DM tells you one useful piece of tactical information, such as its damage vulnerabilities, resistances, immunities, or whether it is above or below half its maximum hit points.

bullets.content: This is especially useful for characters with high mental stats who want to contribute tactically beyond their primary role in combat.

title: Swap Weapons**
subtitle: Sheathe one, draw another
description: A house rule that allows sheathing one weapon and drawing another as a single bonus action.
summary: A house rule that allows you to use your bonus action to sheathe a weapon you are holding and draw a different one, bypassing the normal action cost for a second object interaction.

bullets.content: The standard rules for object interaction can be cumbersome for characters who switch between melee and ranged weapons. This house rule streamlines that process into a single bonus action.

items: As a bonus action, you can sheathe a weapon you are holding and draw a different weapon.
This would normally require your action after using your one free object interaction for the turn.

bullets.content: This is particularly helpful for characters with the Thrown Weapon Fighting style or those who need to switch from a two-handed weapon to have a hand free for spellcasting.

title: Tactical Repositioning**
subtitle: A mini-disengage
description: A house rule that grants a 5-foot step as a bonus action, avoiding an opportunity attack from one creature.
summary: A house rule that allows you to use your bonus action to move 5 feet. This movement does not provoke an opportunity attack from one creature of your choice.

bullets.content: This homebrew provides a more limited but less costly version of the Disengage action, allowing for small, tactical shifts in position without sacrificing your main action.

items: As a bonus action, you can move 5 feet to an unoccupied space.
This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks from one creature of your choice that you can see.

bullets.content: This is useful for getting out of a grapple, moving to a flanking position, or stepping out from behind cover to attack without drawing a reaction from every nearby enemy.
